awd_titl_txt: CC* Network Design: Network Upgrades to Improve Engagement in Science Discovery and Education
awd_abstract_narration:
Truman State University, with the support of the Missouri Research and Education Network (MOREnet) and the University of Missouri, is upgrading the campus network and infrastructure to better enable access to, and use of, scientific data through improved data transfer capabilities for large datasets.  The enhanced infrastructure supports faculty and undergraduate research in understanding star spots, quantifying light pollution in geographical areas, understanding the inhibition mechanisms of drugs to treat global health issues, natural language processing to improve approaches in artificial intelligence, and building low-cost, real-time, soil sensors.  An expanded curriculum that includes hands-on training in cybersecurity and IPv6 technologies is also enabled by utilizing these network resources.  

The improvements include upgrades to the network switch and distribution technologies that result in a ten-fold increase in data transfer and access rates for faculty in STEM-related disciplines, as well as increases in the data transfer bandwidth to the campus observatory, deployment of IPv6 in support of the computer science curriculum, establishment of network performance metrics to inform continued growth, and robust and secure access (through federated identity management) to off-campus research tools and intra-institutional collaboration opportunities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project enhanced Truman State University?s campus network and infrastructure resulting in improved access to, and use of, scientific data within the scholarly and education missions of the University.  These upgrades included: 1) A re-architected campus network that supports a ten-fold increase in data access rates for faculty in Chemistry, Physics, Statistics, Computer Science, and other STEM-related disciplines; 2) Improved data transfer rates for large data sets; 3) Increased bandwidth to the University observatory to support the transfer of large data sets for research and education efforts; 4) Implementation of better network monitoring tools to ensure that the network infrastructure continues to evolve to meet the needs of faculty research both now and in the future; 5) Implementation of a federated identity strategy to securely support access to and use of off-campus research tools; and 6) Deployment of IPv6 in support of changes to the computer science curriculum.

 

As a result of these upgrades, individuals conducting research in the STEM fields are able to conduct more data-intensive collection and analysis due to very high-speed connection to workstations, instrumentation, and the internet (including utilization of supercomputing resource centers).  This has led to a more in-depth understanding of star spots, quantifying light pollution in geographical areas, and understanding the inhibition mechanisms of drugs to treat global health issues.  It has also resulted in improvements to high-throughput computational research completed on various supercomputer clusters across the country (e.g. California, Texas, South Carolina, etc).  In addition, the capability to do remote observations has greatly enhanced the ?duty cycle? of the Observatory facility (having continuous coverage on targets significantly improves the quality of research, as it is now possible to observe changes from one phase cycle to another, ensuring data collection is not intermittent or disjointed).

 

The improvements in instruction have expanded the curriculum to include hands-on training in cybersecurity and IPv6 technologies.  These changes enable students to better understand the IPv4 and IPv6 protocols and the role of each in modern web applications, provide an overview of threats and countermeasures unique to the IPv6 protocol, and facilitates hands-on experience studying gigabit end-user devices, Internet2 routing and infrastructure, and IPv6 protocols.

 

While research and instruction have greatly benefited from these upgrades, the overall management infrastructure benefited from these changes as well.  Utilizing perfSONAR ensures the network infrastructure can continue to evolve to meet the needs of faculty research both now and in the future, and along with this network monitoring tool, the implementation of a federated identity strategy (inCommon and Eduroam) ensures access to additional shared research tools.
